title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #84: Counting Cycle Sets**

**Setup:** The cycle set of a graph G is the set of cycle lengths occurring in G.

**Question:** How many distinct cycle sets are there for n-vertex graphs?

**Status:**
- Part 1 (f(n) = o(2^n)): SOLVED
- Part 2 (f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞): OPEN
mathContext: f(n) counts achievable cycle sets. Not all subsets of {3,...,n} are achievable - there are structural constraints.

title: Cycle Set
content:
**cycleSet G:**

The set of all cycle lengths that occur in graph G.

**Example:**
- K₅ (complete): {3, 4, 5}
- C₆ (6-cycle): {6}
- Path: ∅

This is always contained in {3, ..., n} for an n-vertex graph.

title: Achievable Cycle Sets and f(n)
content:
**isAchievableCycleSet n A:**

A subset A ⊆ {3,...,n} is achievable if some n-vertex graph has cycle set exactly A.

**f(n):**

The count of achievable cycle sets.

**Key Question:** Not all 2^{n-2} subsets are achievable - how many are?

title: Erdős-Faudree Bounds
content:
**erdos_faudree_bounds:**

2^{n/2} < f(n) ≤ 2^{n-2}

**Lower bound:** Construction shows at least 2^{n/2} cycle sets are achievable.

**Upper bound:** Trivial - at most 2^{n-2} subsets of {3,...,n}.

The gap between these bounds is the heart of the problem.

title: Verstraëte's Theorem
content:
**verstraete_theorem (2004):**

f(n) ≪ 2^{n - n^{1/10}}

**Implication:** f(n) = o(2^n), solving Part 1.

**Key insight:** Cycle sets have structural constraints - certain combinations of cycle lengths are impossible.

This was the first proof that f(n) grows strictly slower than 2^n.

title: Nenadov's Improvement
content:
**nenadov_theorem (2025):**

f(n) ≪ 2^{n - n^{1/2 - o(1)}}

**Improvement:** Exponent went from 1/10 to nearly 1/2.

This is a major improvement - the savings in the exponent went from n^{0.1} to almost n^{0.5}.

**Note:** This is recent research (2025), showing the problem is actively studied.

title: Part 2: The Open Question
content:
**part2_statement:**

Does f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞ as n → ∞?

**STATUS: OPEN**

This asks: is the lower bound 2^{n/2} far from tight?

If true, it means f(n) grows strictly faster than 2^{n/2}, improving Erdős-Faudree.

title: The Limit Question
content:
**limit_exists:**

Does lim_{n→∞} f(n)^{1/n} exist?

**If it exists, call it L:**
- L ≥ √2 (from lower bound)
- L ≤ 2 (from upper bound)

**STATUS: OPEN**

Determining whether this limit exists, and its value, would completely characterize the growth rate.

title: Structural Constraints
content:
**structural_constraint:**

There exist subsets A ⊆ {3,...,n} that are NOT achievable cycle sets.

**Why?** Certain cycle lengths force or forbid others:
- Having a triangle might force other cycle lengths
- Some combinations are geometrically impossible

This is why f(n) < 2^{n-2}.

title: Summary: PARTIALLY SOLVED
